content.text: The 17th and 18th centuries saw logic treated as part of epistemology — the study of knowledge. The **Port-Royal Logic** (1662) combined logic with psychology and rhetoric, becoming hugely influential.

**Gottfried Leibniz** (1646-1716) dreamed of a 'universal characteristic' — a perfect logical language in which all reasoning could be reduced to calculation. This vision would later inspire the development of modern symbolic logic.

content.definition: The vision of reducing all reasoning to symbolic calculation. Disputes would be settled by saying 'Let us calculate!' rather than arguing. This anticipated modern formal logic and computation.

content.text: **Immanuel Kant** (1724-1804) famously declared that logic was complete and needed no further development. He distinguished between 'general logic' (pure formal principles) and 'transcendental logic' (conditions for experience).

content.title: Kant's Assessment of Logic
premises: Logic, since Aristotle, 'has not been able to advance a single step'
content.note: Within 100 years of Kant's declaration, Frege would revolutionize logic beyond recognition.

content.text: George Boole (1815-1864) and Augustus De Morgan made logic algebraic, treating propositions like mathematical equations. Boole's Laws of Thought (1854) showed logical reasoning could be expressed in algebraic form.

content.question: What was Leibniz's vision for logic?
options: To reduce all reasoning to symbolic calculation
content.explanation: Leibniz envisioned a 'universal characteristic' — a symbolic language in which reasoning could be reduced to calculation. This anticipated modern formal logic and computer science.
